title: Syriac (1555) Gospels - Kaspar Kraft (WDL-9917)
title_vernacular: ܟܬܒܐ ܕܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܕܡܪܢ ܘܐܠܗܢ ܝܫܘܥ ܡܫܝܚܐ
description:
The first printed edition of the Syriac New Testament was produced in 1555 under the patronage of Ferdinand I, a significant milestone in the history of biblical texts. Key contributors to this edition included Johann Albrecht Widmanstetter, a pivotal figure in the study of Eastern languages in Europe, and Moses of Mardin, whose handwriting influenced the Syriac typeface created for this publication by Kaspar Kraft under the guidance of French Orientalist Guillaume Postel.

This edition is distinguished by its content, including the books of James, 1 Peter, and 1 John, but notably excluding the other General Epistles and the Book of Revelation. The book is also remarkable for its artistic elements, featuring woodcuts with Hapsburg motifs, Syriac and Latin inscriptions, and a unique illustration of the crucifixion paired with the Kabbalistic Sephirot at the beginning of the Gospel of John. These artistic additions highlight the cultural and religious significance of the work.

Designed for liturgical use, this edition concludes with a Syriac and Latin table of lectionary readings, underscoring its practical application in Christian worship. The 1555 Syriac New Testament thus stands as a key artifact in the history of biblical scholarship, showcasing a fusion of religious, linguistic, and cultural elements of its time.
